;

;

;“除了讨论我们与洪都拉斯继续合作以安全、安全的方式减少非正常移民外，该部门周五表示，国务卿将以有序和人道的方式监督西南边境执法行动，并强调以合法途径作为打击走私者的替代方案。

;

;;2023 年 9 月 21 日，美国总统乔·拜登在华盛顿白宫椭圆形办公室拥抱乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基。 路透社/Kevin Lamarque/资料照片;
;

;美国全国广播公司新闻周五援引三名美国官员和国会官员。<​​/p>;

;基辅多次要求拜登政府提供陆军战术导弹系统（ATACMS），以帮助攻击和破坏俄罗斯占领领土上的补给线、空军基地和铁路网络。

;

;但是，当泽伦斯基周四访问华盛顿与拜登会谈时，白宫并未透露有关 ATACMS 的任何决定，尽管白宫宣布了向基辅提供 3.25 亿美元的新军事援助计划。

;

;五角大楼没有立即回应应路透社的置评请求。

;

;路透社此前报道称，拜登政府正在考虑向乌克兰运送 ATACMS，其飞行距离可达 190 英里（306 公里）。

;

;ATACMS 的设计美国陆军网站称，“对敌方第二梯队部队进行纵深攻击”，可用于攻击前线后方的指挥和控制中心、防空系统和后勤站点。

;

;拜登向泽连斯基保证周四，尽管一些共和党议员反对提供更多数十亿美元的援助，但美国仍将维持对他击退俄罗斯侵略者的战争的强烈支持。

;

;泽伦斯基周四感谢拜登提供的最新武器包，包括空中武器防御，说“它正是我们的士兵现在所需要的。”

;;阿塞拜疆总统外交政策顾问希克梅特·哈吉耶夫在阿塞拜疆军队本周占领卡拉巴赫飞地后接受路透社采访时表示，阿塞拜疆计划对放弃武器的亚美尼亚战士进行大赦。;
;;
;; 2023 年 9 月 21 日，在亚美尼亚埃里温举行集会，要求亚美尼亚总理尼科尔·帕辛扬 (Nikol Pashinyan) 在纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫投降后辞职。 执法人员在政府大楼外站岗。Hayk Baghdasaryan/Photolure via REUTERS/file photo;
;

;分离的纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫的亚美尼亚族领导层周五表示，在阿塞拜疆的闪电攻势迫使他们达成一项耻辱性的停火协议后，尚未与阿塞拜疆就安全保障或大赦达成协议。

; >;

;卡拉巴赫及其 12 万亚美尼亚人的未来悬而未决：阿塞拜疆希望整合这个长期争议的地区，但亚美尼亚人表示，他们担心自己会受到迫害，并指责世界抛弃了他们。

;

;阿塞拜疆总统外交政策顾问希克梅特·哈吉耶夫 (Hikmet Hajiyev) 告诉路透社，巴库计划对放弃武器的卡拉巴赫亚美尼亚战士进行大赦，尽管其中一些人发誓要继续抵抗。

;

;“对于前……战斗人员……我们正在设想大赦或暗示大赦，”他说。

;

;但卡拉巴赫亚美尼亚人称其领土为阿尔扎赫共和国，表示尚未达成协议。

;

;“这些问题仍然必须得到解决，”这个自封的共和国总统萨姆维尔·沙赫拉马尼扬 (Samvel Shahramanyan) 的顾问戴维·巴巴扬 (David Babayan) 告诉路透社。 “目前还没有具体结果。”

;

;不过，巴巴扬表示，已经达成协议，一支人道主义车队将于周五从亚美尼亚经拉钦走廊（一条穿越阿塞拜疆领土的公路）前往卡拉巴赫。

;

; >;

;“情况非常困难：人们挨饿，没有电，没有燃料——我们有很多难民，”他说。

;

;包括大型卡车在内的七辆俄罗斯维和车辆驶过现场的一名路透社记者称，周五亚美尼亚检查站正前往纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫。

;

;在本周的迅速军事行动之后，阿塞拜疆总统伊利哈姆·阿利耶夫发誓要保障亚美尼亚族人的权利，但表示他的“铁杆”拳头”将他们关于亚美尼亚卡拉巴赫独立的想法变成了历史。他说，作为阿塞拜疆的一部分，该地区将变成“天堂”。

;

;他的国家在土耳其的支持下，对卡拉巴赫战士拥有军事优势。但目前尚不清楚有多少武装分子准备放下武器，也不清楚目前正在讨论的更全面协议将采取何种形式。

;

;亚美尼亚和阿塞拜疆都是苏联的一部分，自 1991 年卡拉巴赫垮台以来，该国曾为该地区爆发过两场战争。该地区被国际承认为阿塞拜疆的一部分，但在亚美尼亚的支持下，在过去三十年中享有事实上的独立。

;

;鉴于两国之间的血腥历史，许多亚美尼亚人对将会发生的事情感到恐惧

;

;“我们唯一的希望就是俄罗斯维和人员的帮助。世界对此视而不见，不想听到任何声音。我们认为，如果没有维和人员，哪怕一小时，居住在阿塞拜疆边境附近的亚美尼亚人格里戈尔·扎哈扬 (Grigor Zakharyan) 说：“我们将会发生种族灭绝。”

;

;阿塞拜疆声称取得了对该地区的胜利，这为纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫山区的动荡历史带来了另一个转折。几个世纪以来，一直受到波斯人、土耳其人、俄罗斯人、奥斯曼人和苏联人的影响。

;

;这也可能改变南高加索地区微妙的权力平衡，该地区被;俄罗斯、美国、土耳其和伊朗所在的石油和天然气管道;争夺影响力。

;

;阿塞拜疆总统外交政策顾问哈吉耶夫表示，卡拉巴赫亚美尼亚人的权利将受到尊重，作为他们融入阿塞拜疆的一部分。他说，三批人道主义援助物资将于周五运抵该地区。

;

;哈吉耶夫表示，一些卡拉巴赫军队和军官已承诺继续抵抗。他说：“当然，这会带来一定的挑战和困难，但规模不会这么大。”

;

;亚美尼亚总理尼科尔·帕希尼扬(Nikol Pashinyan)在埃里温面临卡拉巴赫问题要求他辞职的抗议活动，表示政府已为可能的流离失所者涌入亚美尼亚准备了空间，但不想减少卡拉巴赫的人口。

;

;“我们必须尽一切努力......以便我们的同胞，纳戈尔诺-卡拉巴赫的居民俄罗斯在卡拉巴赫驻有近 2,000 名维和人员，该国呼吁保持冷静，但遭到一些亚美尼亚人的指责，其中包括帕希尼扬在支持亚美尼亚方面做得不够。

;

;在社交媒体上发布的一段视频中，两名男子向埃里温的俄罗斯大使馆投掷红色油漆。

;

;数千名卡拉巴赫亚美尼亚人被根据社交媒体上发布的图片，仍然聚集在一些俄罗斯维和人员驻扎的当地机场。

;

;“我们需要看到国际社会的承诺，而不是漠不关心，”一名俄罗斯维和人员鲁本·瓦尔达尼扬 (Ruben Vardanyan) 说。分离政府前国务部长。

;

;巴巴扬表示，由于该地区实际上已被围困，因此尚未发生大规模人员流动。

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 23:55:04 +0800 Stocks rise, yields slip as market mulls Fed“s outlookhttps://reuters.com/article/global-markets/stocks-rise-yields-slip-as-market-mulls-feds-outlook-idUSKBN30S04F
;;2023-09-22T15:45:03Z;
;

;美国国债价格和全球股市指标在本周早些时候美联储宣布大幅抛售后出现反弹警告利率将保持在较高水平，许多市场人士认为这一消息与其软着陆预测不一致。

;

;美联储政策制定者将美国央行隔夜贷款利率预测上调 50 个基点至 5.1% 2024年，还上调了经济增长预期。然而，较高的利率通常会抑制银行贷款并提高信贷成本。

;

;“在较长一段时间内将利率保持在这一水平或略高于这一水平，这一切都不符合，”Marvin Loh 说，波士顿道富银行高级全球宏观策略师。

;

;“当然，他们希望传达这样的信息：更高的价格将持续更长时间，因此他们全力以赴实现软着陆。与此相关的一些不一致之处.”

;

;摩根士丹利资本国际 (MSCI) 以美国为中心的全球股市表现和华尔街股市反弹，而与价格走势相反的美元和国债收益率则回落。基准 10 年期国债从超过 4.5% 的 16 年高点回落。

;

;反映利率预期的两年期国债收益率下跌 3.6 个基点，至 5.112%。

;

;作为增长放缓的迹象，;闪读<标准普尔全球美国综合 PMI 指数显示，9 月份美国商业活动基本停滞，庞大的服务业基本上以 2 月份以来最慢的速度闲置。

;

;美联储对更高利率的初步重新评估-长期政策推动美国国债收益率上升，给股票、信贷和新兴市场等风险资产带来阻力，但支撑了美元。

;

;MSCI 全球国家股票指数;(.MIWD00000PUS); 上涨 0.37%，但泛欧 STOXX 600 指数 ;(.STOXX); 下跌 0.39%。

;

;在华尔街，道琼斯工业平均指数;(.DJI);上涨0.17%，标准普尔500指数;(.SPX); 上涨 0.53%，纳斯达克综合指数 ;(.IXIC); 上涨 0.83%。

;

;在货币市场，PMI 初值发布后，美元兑一篮子货币回吐涨幅，但仍上涨 0.10%，至 105.48。

;

;日元兑美元汇率在早前因;日本央行;决定将利率维持在负值，这表明它并不急于逐步取消大规模刺激计划。

;

;由于俄罗斯燃料出口禁令重新引发全球供应担忧，抵消了宏观经济逆风和利率上升引发的需求担忧，油价上涨。

;

;美国原油期货 CLc1>;上涨 0.79%，至每桶 90.34 美元，布伦特原油价格报 93.77 美元，当日上涨 0.5%。

;

;与美国经济形成鲜明对比的是，;欧元区经济可能在第三季度收缩，并且不会很快恢复增长显示，打击了欧元和收益率。

;

;MSCI 亚太股票指数（日本除外）;(.MIAPJ0000PUS);触及10个月低点，随后因中国承诺支持私营企业而反弹，上涨0.9%。本周下跌 2.8%。

;

;日本日经指数 ;(.N225)< /a>; 削减了高达 1% 的跌幅，交易价格下跌了 0.5%。

;

;日本十年期国债期货上涨，但现金收益率几乎没有变化，接近十年高点 0.745%。

;

;本周，投资者仍在消化主要央行的一系列政策决定。

;

;各国央行;瑞典;和;挪威;宣布加息25个基点，并有可能进一步加息。

;

;然而;英格兰银行;在一项意见分歧的决定中，近两年来首次维持利率不变，英镑走强跌至六个月低点，而瑞士法郎在瑞士国家银行意外维持利率后大幅下跌。

;

;“有很多混杂的信息和故事，而且通常是在转折点附近出现的”，惠灵顿新西兰银行高级经济学家 Craig Ebert 表示。

;

;在新兴市场，印度债券和卢比在;摩根大通;表示将把印度债务纳入其广泛追踪的;新兴市场指数;，为数十亿美元的外资流入奠定了基础。< /p>;

;受美元和债券收益率小幅回调的推动，金价小幅走高，因投资者考虑美联储的强硬立场，并等待政策制定者的评论以获取有关利率前景的线索。

;

;现货在连续三个交易日下跌后，金价上涨 0.3%，至每盎司 1,924.60 美元。

;美国联邦储备委员会官员周五警告称，即使在投票决定将基准联邦基金利率稳定在本周举行的会议上，两位政策制定者表示，他们仍然不相信通胀斗争已经结束。

;

;他们的评论受到“耐心”等词语的缓和，并承认价格上涨已经放缓。

;<但央行本周同意将基准利率稳定在5.25%至5.50%区间以来的首次公开评论中，强调的是利率仍可能上升的可能性，以及货币政策政策保持紧缩的时间可能会比之前预期的更长。

;

;“通货膨胀仍然过高，我预计（联邦公开市场）委员会进一步加息并将其保持在限制性水平可能是适当的美联储理事米歇尔·鲍曼 (Michelle Bowman) 在为科罗拉多州独立社区银行家活动准备的讲话中表示，“我们将在一段时间内保持通胀水平，以便及时将通胀率恢复到 2% 的目标。”

;

;“通胀方面的进展可能会是鉴于目前的货币政策限制水平，通胀增长缓慢。”她表示，并指出，在美联储本周早些时候发布的政策制定者预测中，通胀“至少到 2025 年底”仍将高于 2% 的目标。

;

;她指出，能源价格潜在的进一步上涨是她正在监测的一个特殊风险。

;

;波士顿联储行长苏珊·柯林斯在向缅因州银行家协会发表的另一场讲话中表示，进一步收紧货币政策“肯定是并非不可能，”尽管她也建议“保持耐心”，因为美联储试图从有时嘈杂的通胀数据中获取正确的信号。

;

;“现在就确信通胀处于可持续轨道上还为时过早回到 2% 的目标，”柯林斯表示，就业增长仍然“高于趋势”，服务业方面的通胀上升仍然令人担忧。

;

;“我预计利率可能必须保持在较高水平，柯林斯表示：“预计美联储将在周五晚些时候发表讲话。” -会议政策评论被取消。

;

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 23:25:04 +0800 UAW strike set to hit deep into the industry“s supply basehttps://reuters.com/article/auto-labor-uaw-suppliers/uaw-strike-set-to-hit-deep-into-the-industrys-supply-base-idUSKBN30S1CH
;;2023-09-22T15:20:35Z;
;

;Jeffrey Aznavorian has already cut output about 6% at his small auto parts factory outside Detroit due to the United Auto Workers strike. But he is bracing for it to get worse.

;

;Much worse.

;

;The union, which initiated strikes at three plants last week, one of each owned by Ford ;(FN);, General Motors ;(GM.N);, and Chrysler parent Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);, on Friday announced it would expand the action ;to 38 parts distribution facilities; in 20 states owned by GM and Stellantis. The union said it was not expanding its action against Ford, because the parties had made progress in talks.

;

;The first week of the strike was costly. Michigan economic consulting firm Anderson Economic Group LLC estimates total economic losses have totaled over $1.6 billion so far, largely concentrated in the handful of areas where strike actions or layoffs have already occurred.

;

;The expanded strike will ricochet through the industry's vast supplier networks.

;

;It comes at a time when the US job market has cooled but remains robust. The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits dropped to an eight-month low last week. But a rebound in jobless claims is expected in coming weeks as the strike forces auto manufacturers and their suppliers to temporarily lay off workers.

;

;Some producers are already doing it. Auto parts maker CIE Newcor, a subsidiary of Spain's CIE Automotive, notified workers last week that it would temporarily lay off 300 workers at four Michigan plants, starting Oct. 2, due to the strike.

;

;The supply base for the Detroit Three, as they're called, reaches deep into the economy, especially in the upper Midwest, and touches everything from chemical and metal producers to electronics.

;

;US Steel ;(XN); on Tuesday said it would idle its only operating blast furnace at a plant in Illinois due to an anticipated drop in demand from the auto industry during the strike. In a statement, the Pittsburgh steelmaker said it was “executing our risk mitigation plan” - but declined to say how many workers would be affected.

;

;Industry analysts and smaller producers interviewed by Reuters said an expanded or prolonged strike could do permanent damage to the industry's network of 5,600 mostly small or mid-size suppliers, which employ an estimated 660,000 workers.

;

;"A lot of these companies were just starting to get their legs underneath them again" after COVID and semiconductor chip shortages, said Laurie Harbour, CEO of Harbour Results Inc., a manufacturing advisory firm in Southfield, Michigan.

;

;If the strike expands, it would only be a matter of weeks before some smaller suppliers faltered, said Marick Masters, a professor of business at Wayne State University.

;

;"Many of them would find it very difficult to survive that," he said. "Certainly, they would have to lay off workers - it's just a question of how long they could go without revenue." He estimates 30% of smaller suppliers carry too much debt to survive a long strike.

;

;Other measures also point to a supply base that was strained even before the strike. James Gellert, executive chairman of RapidRatings, a financial analytics firm, said the automakers and their largest suppliers are relatively healthy. But moving deeper into the supply chain, "we find smaller, mostly private companies that rely on limited sources of capital."

;

;Gellert noted that many of these firms depleted their cash reserves during the pandemic. And now, with higher interest rates and tougher borrowing conditions from banks, many of them are vulnerable.

;

;RapidRatings calculates "core health scores" for privately owned auto parts companies - based on a 100-point scale - which looks at their returns, cost structures, and capital structure. That gauge deteriorated 10.7%, from 39.7 to 35.4, over the past year.

;

;Back at Aznavorian's company, Clips & Clamps Industries in Plymouth, Michigan, it's "still business as usual," he said. However, he added, he is ready to start "sleeping at the factory" if that is what it takes to minimize disruptions and keep production going whatever the fallout from the strike.

; Fri, 22 Sep 2023 23:25:04 +0800 Explainer: UAW expands strikes against GM, Stellantis in fight over new contracthttps://reuters.com/article/autos-labor-uaw-stakes-explainer/explainer-uaw-expands-strikes-against-gm-stellantis-in-fight-over-new-contract-idUSKBN30S1CB
;;2023-09-22T15:22:12Z;
;;
;;A caravan of striking United Auto Workers from the Jeep plant in Toledo, Ohio, drive past striking Ford UAW members in solidarity outside the Ford Michigan Assembly Plant in Wayne, Michigan US September 19, 2023. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook;
;

;The United Auto Workers (UAW) union on Friday expanded its coordinated US strike against General Motors Co ;(GM.N); and Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);, but said it had made real progress in talks with Ford Motor ;(FN);.

;

;The ongoing strike is the first-ever simultaneous labor action against General Motors ;(GM.N);, Ford Motor ;(FN); and Chrysler parent Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI); after the UAW's contracts expired more than a week ago.

;

;The automakers, like their global counterparts, have been focused on cost reductions, which in some cases include job cuts, to help accelerate a shift to electric vehicles (EVs) from gasoline-powered vehicles.

;

;The UAW, which represents 46,000 GM workers, 57,000 Ford employees and 43,000 Stellantis workers, kicked off negotiations with the companies in July.

;

;The union historically has picked one of the Detroit Three to negotiate with first as the so-called target that sets the pattern on which subsequent deals are based. This time, UAW President Shawn Fain targeted all three companies simultaneously.

;

;Contract talks between the UAW and the Detroit automakers in past years had gone on until the strike deadline and beyond. A ;Reuters/Ipsos poll; found significant support by Americans for the striking auto workers.

;

;The initial walkout of 12,700 workers was smaller than some analysts expected, with only three assembly plants in Michigan, Ohio and Missouri targeted. Those plants build the Ford Bronco, Jeep Wrangler and Chevrolet Colorado, along with other popular models.

;

;The second round of strikes will expand to 38 locations across 20 states in all nine regions of the UAW, focusing on parts distribution centers.

;

;The union previously ;rejected; the companies' offers. It has demanded a 40% wage hike, including a 20% immediate increase, and improvements in benefits.

;

;"If they've got money for Wall Street, they sure as hell have money for the workers making the product," UAW President ;Shawn Fain; has said.

;

;Fain said on Friday "Stellantis and GM in particular are going to need some serious pushing." He added they have more work to do at Ford, but "we do want to recognize that Ford is showing they're serious about reaching a deal."

;

;The three automakers currently have proposed 20% raises over four-and-a-half years. In an opinion piece published in the Detroit Free Press, GM President Mark Reuss called the UAW's demands for a 40% pay hike "untenable," signaling the two sides remain far apart over the key issue.

;

;On Friday, Fain said Ford has improved its offer, which includes right to strike over plant closures, additional job security in the event of layoffs and enhanced profit sharing formula.

;

;The industrial action hit the Detroit Three automakers as they ramp up efforts to maximize gasoline and EV vehicle production to capitalize on ;demand for new vehicles;.

;

;A full strike would hit earnings at each affected automaker by about $400 million to $500 million per week assuming all production was lost, Deutsche Bank previously estimated. Some losses could be recouped by boosting production schedules later, but that possibility fades if a strike extends to weeks or months.

;

;In fiscal 2019, GM's fourth-quarter profit took a $3.6 billion hit from a 40-day UAW strike.

;

;Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas estimated in a Thursday research note that a full month of lost production would cost the three automakers $7 billion to $8 billion in lost profits.

;

;The UAW is pushing automakers to eliminate the two-tier wage system under which new hires can earn far less than veterans.

;

;Fain has said repeatedly that the union will push to restore pay improvements tied to the cost of living and retiree benefits cut during the 2008-2009 economic crisis.

;

;The UAW wants strong salary increases, given the financial success of the automakers, citing generous executive payouts and large US federal subsidies for EV sales.

;

;The union also wants defined benefit pensions for all workers restored, 32-hour work weeks, job security guarantees and an end to the use of temporary workers.

;

;Fain also is aiming to get agreements that would allow the UAW to represent hourly workers at joint-venture EV battery plants opened or planned by the Detroit Three.

;

;The UAW has been wary of the industry shift to EVs and ;called; on the Biden administration to soften its proposed vehicle emission cuts that would require 67% of new vehicles to be electric by 2032. The union has yet to endorse a candidate in the next US presidential election.

;

;EVs require fewer parts to build, and industry officials have said that will result in a need for fewer workers. Fain has said there should be no jobs lost because of the EV shift.

;

;The Detroit Three want to close the cost gap they have with foreign automakers with non-unionized US factories.

;

;Ford sources estimate that their US labor costs are $64 an hour, compared with an estimated $55 for foreign automakers and $45 to $50 for EV leader Tesla ;(TSLA.O);.

;

;The companies also want greater flexibility in how they use their US workforces to increase efficiency and cut costs as the industry shifts to EVs.
